docs.snippet: Facebook and Twitter faced fallout from the ways they had been used during the election, and Snapchat’s parent released video-recording glasses.

headline.main: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Fake News, Trolls and Other Spectacles

docs.snippet: Questions continue to swirl over Facebook’s handling of fake news stories and a tool it created that could potentially be used to censor content in China.

headline.main: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: More Debate Over Facebook’s Role in Media

docs.snippet: The Haggler looks back on 2016 and finds a long list of companies behaving badly.

headline.main: Looking for Holiday Cheer? Look Elsewhere

docs.snippet: Hillary Clinton’s generation aimed to free women from domestic prisons. But work is a prison, too.
With debit cards rather than bagged food, refugees buy their produce, live in more dignity, and raise less resentment among their Lebanese neighbors.

headline.main: For Refugees in Lebanon, Cash Instead of Camps

docs.snippet: Despite some hiccups, real-time voter turnout data landed VoteCastr on people’s radar screens, and Twitter proved its centrality in big news events.

headline.main: Daily Report: The Tech Companies That Won on Election Day

docs.snippet: An uproar ensued over an image of a professor at an evangelical Christian school and a caption that said that Christians and Muslims worship the same deity.

headline.print_headline: In Uproar Over Facebook Post, Familiar Debate on Monotheism
headline.main: Facebook Post Revives Debate on Whether Monotheists Worship Same God

docs.abstract: Mark Oppenheimer Beliefs column examines controversial statement made by Wheaton College Prof Larycia Hawkins, in which she claimed solidarity with Muslims as they worship same God she worships as Christian, which led to her leaving her position at college; notes idea that monotheistic traditions of Judaism, Christianity and Islam share same God has support from people in all three traditions.

docs.snippet: A district of Brussels had in effect seceded from Belgium. Europe must fight an ideological battle against Wahhabi Islam.
Complaints on social media by two deputy governors besieged by Taliban, Qaeda and Islamic State fighters were not viewed kindly by the government of President Ashraf Ghani.

headline.print_headline: Afghan Officials Voicing Security Concerns Online Are Fired for Efforts
headline.main: Afghan Officials, Voicing Security Fears on Facebook, Are Fired for Their Trouble

docs.abstract: Afghan government fires Helmand Province's deputy governor Mohammad Jan Rasoolyar, who used Facebook to plead for help against Taliban offensive; authorities deem move, made after earlier appeals were ignored, to be excessively reckless; episode reflects social media's ongoing ambivalent relationship to official communications.

docs.snippet: Let’s demolish the outdated notion that women in positions of power are bad for other women.

headline.print_headline: The Myth of the Catty Woman
